sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving gases
message_1:
What is the standard enthalpy change for the reaction 2NO(g) + O2(g) → 2NO2(g)? Provided with the following thermochemical equations: 

2NO(g) + O2(g) → 2NO2 (g) ΔH° = -113.1 kJ/mol 

1/2N2(g) + O2(g) → NO2 (g) ΔH° = -33.2 kJ/mol 

1/2N2(g) + O2(g) → NO (g) ΔH° = -90.25 kJ/mol 

NO(g) + 1/2O2(g) → NO2(g) ΔH° = -56.2 kJ/mol
message_2:
The standard enthalpy change for the reaction 2NO(g) + O2(g) → 2NO2(g) is already provided in the first thermochemical equation:

2NO(g) + O2(g) → 2NO2 (g) ΔH° = -113.1 kJ/mol

So, the standard enthalpy change for this reaction is -113.1 kJ/mol.
